												Absolutely, unquestionably, the worst attempt at a "AAA" game that I've seen in a very long time. It's so incredibly bad, that I got the distinct feeling of being swindled. Like, old-timey swindled, by a man wearing a stolen coat, selling a bottle of cure-all on the corner of two dirt roads, with a pet monkey napping on the hood of his dusty car.I'm serious. It's so bad, that they had to know it was bad. They knew it was bad, and put it up for pre-order and release, knowing they'd rake in a rather large sum of money before the game was playable.How is it bad - there is no single way in which it is good. The voice acting is worse than the most pathetic attempt at game-making by students. Junior High School students. The graphics look as though they were brought here from 2004. The storyline is all but non-existent. The writing is about on-par with that of a 3rd grader. The character design is something you'd see in the back of a homework folder on that weird kid's desk in High School - you know, the one who thinks he's an artist, but can't draw. The ship, there's only one by the way, is all of 3 rooms, only two which can you walk in, and there is zero interactability within those rooms.The pilot interface is awful. The entire game interface is awful. It's very clearly made as a console port, except they never said a word about consoles and released to PC first. The game is riddled with so many crippling bugs, that it's literally unplayable. After only 20 minutes, I was forced to restart, because a game-breaking bug halted any progress that could made. The music, for which they attempted to sell pre-release soundtracks, is mediocre at best, and only by a 2004 standard. The interior of space stations is the same, in every station. The NPC speech is apalling, they say hello, then immediatley say something rude to you, and cut off speech. There basically isn't any reason to speak to any of them. In fact, there isn't any reason to *do* anything at all. They touted the game to be so many things, but in the end, it isn't even playable. Do not waste your money on this game.

												I never played an "X" game before, which will make this review of more use to those of you who also haven't and just want to know if this is a good game, and less use to those of you who have, and want to know how it stacks up to its predecessors. I thought I might start with an anecdote.Tasked with building a space station in an ally's territory, I only needed about 60 fusion reactors to complete it. I searched every sector for it, but nobody was selling. I soon found out why: these were only being produced at 3 stations and my enemy, the Plutarch Corporation, owned one of those and was buying every reactor that came off the production lines at the others. So what's a poor rebel to do?Raid their shipments, obviously.I waited several kilometers away from one of the factories with my cargo freighter standing by. After seeing a Plutarch ship dock and then pull away, I scanned its cargo, revealing that it was carrying my coveted fusion reactors, I made my move.I used my dumbfire rockets to quickly disable its engines and warp drive, then went to work on the main hull. This was a long process but I found a safe spot just behind the engines where I could go to recharge my shields. Woe to the unwary freighter that travels without fighter escort.The freighter destroyed, I tagged the cargo for my own cargo ship to pick up. As a swarm of drones buzzed toward the remains, I spotted a Plutarch destroyer in the distance. Several seconds later it was apparent that it was headed straight for me, most likely in response to my little Space Pirate schtick. I had no means to fight a destroyer, but I did tangle with the wing of fighters it sent ahead of itself in order to protect my cargo drones. As the last drone made it safely into the cargo bay, the destroyer began to open up on my freighter. It's a hardy vessel but it wouldn't last long under that hailstorm of fire. I ordered the captain of the freighter to get us out of there, then swung my craft around to the front, briefly exposing myself to the destroyer's fire to dock. I watched from the deck as lasers streaked across the sky and missiles exploded against the hull, hearing the faint sound of the frieghter's jump drive charging up. Moments later, explosions were replaced by silence. The jump had taken me and my freighter hundreds of thousands of kilometers away, with our precious reactors safely aboard (and with no load screen in between).I chose this little anecdote because it perfectly encapsulates X: Rebirth's interacting systems of trade, construction, and combat. But I neglected to mention a few details.During this whole scenario, I encountered a massive drop in framerate that persisted until I left the zone and returned. The game crashed inexplicably some time after I transferred my wares. I originally tried boarding the freighter, but found that while 8 marines was plenty to take a destroyer in an earlier story mission, a full complement of 50 marines was totally incapable later on of capturing even a much smaller freighter than my target. The station repeatedly reminded me that my rash behavior "isn't tolerated in these parts," but apparently forgot to attach a consequence to their threats. Even now I can trade with that station as with any other. And the whole excursion was made necessary because my previous shipment of some 114 fusion reactors inexplicably disappeared from the freighter's cargo holds--the freighter made it, the goods didn't. It still had the order to transfer the wares to my construction ship in its queue. Upon deleting and reissuing the order, a message told me that it had no fusion reactors in its holds. Gone into thin air.My point is this: At its best, X: Rebirth is the most full-featured, exciting, strategic space sim available that I know of. Though dogfights are a little awkward because the smaller spacecraft are so maneuverable, combat overall is exceptionally exciting. The game has made me think in terms of real logic (how can I acquire this good by any means available) as opposed to game logic (how can I exploit this system to get 1000x as much as I'll ever need). It appears, so far as I can tell, that the entire game is driven by a real economy: goods cannot be used until they're produced, and producing these goods means someone has to mine them, extract them, refine them, and manufacture them. This creates a living world unlike any I've ever seen before, and when I close my trade console and nudge my throttle forward (I use a Saitek X52 joystick) towards the next station, or merge into a highway and switch on the auto-pilot while I give orders to my fleet, I really feel like I am there, interacting with a real world in space. Seeing a station suddenly pop into view as I exit the space highway, or docking on one of my larger vessels while it jumps me across space (with no loading screens!) are experiences that just never get old.At its worst, X: Rebirth continues to sport more bugs and headaches than are really excusable, especially with it being the fourth iteration in the series. You will encounter glitches. Your framerate will inexplicably drop to a crawl (only happened to me twice in 24 hours play though). You will experience crashes (save often). The story dialogue is fair, but most of the other conversations and text might have actually been written by a third grader (hearing a Marine Officer randomly chirp, valley-girl style, "Eww, slimy green lizardy things are everywhere!" is just bizarre, and some of the logbook entries are so poorly written as to be indecipherable). The game does not explain itself very thoroughly, and you will spend much time trying to figure out how many of its systems work (or don't work, as is occasionally the case).I had great anticipation for this game's release, so I was very disappointed when I read that it was basically an unfinished product. The free weekend just recently spoke a great deal about the developer's confidence in the current state of their product, and I believe that confidence is justified. This is now a very playable, fully-featured game, and if you are patient and have a good tolerance for the occasional bug, it can give you some of the most fantastic gaming experiences you've had in years.

												Final Verdict: 4.12 / 101 - Stability / Engine6/10There have been a couple complaints about FPS drops and crashes.That makes me come to the conclusion, that there are some compatiblity issues, but the majority of players seems to be able to play the game at normal framerates and crashfree.I myself am using a Radeon HD 7970 and experienced a couple frame rate drops here and there, but until now I didn't have anything dramatic happening to me and I'm playing at pretty high settings.There are no hardware caused bugs like graphic bugs, in this perspective it runs without any problems.Things that do stop my gameplay and have me lose the progress since my last manual save are UI-Bugs.I got stuck in the trading menu with the "save" option turned off. The game kept running, but I couldn't close the menu so I had to quit and start over with an old savegame.Another bug is that if you dock on a big carrier with having it's docking platform outside you might experience the carrier flying through everything. It just glitches through the giant space stations as if they aren't there. You better watch your step when going back to your ship.I do not wish to have these bugs influence the score too much because Egosoft used to fix such bugs in previous titles.2 - Gameplay2.1 Learning Curve:3/10The game is once again extremely hard to learn how to play.I take the risk and dare to say it is far harder to understand the game than in previous titles.While previous titles like "X3 Albion Prelude" had icons and colourful effects at every space station and ship telling you "Hey here's a quest!" or "I'm taking damage!" X Rebirth doesn't have that.They wanted to make the gaming experience more intuitive but they did that on the cost of obviousness.As a new player and even as an experienced player of every single previous title you have absolutely no idea what to do or how to actually do it.This comes along with a problem with the UI: it doesn't scale with the resolution!At a for today very normal resolution of 1920:1080 your UI becomes so tiny that it's absolutely not the player's fault if they miss something.The tutorial uses the same lines as the subtitles.Eventhough there is no text overlapping it is still a very bad idea, especially because you constantly get tutorial messages for just piloting the ship during the normal gameplay.2.2 - Human Gameplay1/10During the gameplay it is necessary to stand up from your seat and walk through your tiny ship or some tiny levels that resemble the interriors of a space station.I don't even want to pick on the fact that you don't seem to have a body yourself, what's far worse is that you run through the stations with far too high speed.You can barely interact with your environment and the interactions that are actually there feel very clumsy and poorly designed.It is clear that the development team or the game engine itself is not capable of implementing an organic gameplay within a space game.Together with 3.1, 4.1 and 4.2 the human gameplay is rather a huge bother than an enjoyable side experience.The human gameplay is a requirement to play the game properly and overall I'd say it has the level of the worst games that infect the market with their low-quality rip-off poison, I've seen super-low budget games that did a better job, I'm sorry to say.2.3 - Ship Gameplay5/10I'm pretty nice here because I see the little details they added to the franchise over time.Your ship doesn't just "turn" if you move your mouse, it drifts into the previous direction, till your accelleration overcomes the former vector.You can see your actual speed in real time, there is no restriction when it comes to flying around.I do see the relative speed they added to the game, so you don't get crushed by a carrier, while you're flying inside its docking area or anything.I do see that they really did put some effort into it.But the ship gameplay is not just the 360° controls, it's also the interaction with your environment and that's where the score dies.To interact with a station you have to fly really close to its hovering icon.Often you find yourself clicking and clicking and just not getting that stupid icon to highlight.If you concentrate too much on keeping the icon in the center of your crosshair you will find yourself crashing into the station with mach1 or faster (that doesn't sound healthy).Since they removed the targeting system you're usually left having absolutely no idea where your ships are.At the beginning of the story mode you get a large trading ship, but I couldn't find it!I had no idea how to get to it.It was on my sector map, but I could only get a rough idea of where it must be, I couldn't highlight it.When I finally found it I had to go to the front of the ship to be able to access the docking menu.Being 10m away from a big moving obstacle and moving to it with the speed of sound is a BAD COMBINATION.Aside from that I did notice that the ships you meet in the highway are just there for the minigame.If you leave the highway through its gate none of those ships come out, and there are a lot of ships in there.Previous titles told you when an enemy gets into or out of your weapon's reach, now you have no idea when to shoot.The distances are less detailed now, you only get kilometer displays.2.4 - Menus and Control Panels2/10I wished there was anything enjoyable but not even the main menu feels good.You have to switch to arrow keys + enter/esc to use the menu properly.Mouse input doesn't work very well since you often don't know if the game actually took the double click or not.There are a lot of issues with things like the trading menu.While I already transferred the bugs to the stability rating, the menu also feels unintuitive.I had no idea who trades with whom and in which direction the wares are going.The few menus and control panels that are present are a bother to use!And it's not just what's there: It's also what's not there.I have the strong feeling that the game would have been better off with far more control panels than that.The "intuitive gameplay" is a huge failure and without a proper control interface with a high grade of obviousity you cannot play the game properly.3 - Graphics3.1 - Human Character Models1/10During the gameplay you will soon notice the incredibly ugly character models.Most humans you meet look so old, you'll be afraid they drop dead any second.Aside from the age they look like their parents were very sad fishes.http://cloud-2.steampowered.com/ugc/469793673227446070/40D404604FC504953A6296C198E7CC544F400BA5/3.2 - Human Animations1/10The models are also barely animated.No mocap studio was used for those animations, and you will definately see that.The animations are extremely rudimentary.It is very obvious that someone doesn't know how to rig clothing to a mesh, so you'll often see hats and glasses move differently than the bodypart they are attached to.Also often animations don't fit together and lead to weird dislocations.3.3 - Ship and Station Models6/10I'm sorry to give this such a low rating, because most ships look very beautiful, especially the larger ones.Same goes to the majority of the station models.What's a bother though is that not all of the models look good.Actually some of the models have an incredibly low polygon count for the fact that during the normal gameplay you have to stare at them closeup.Aside from that many parts of the space stations are made of alpha-textures instead of 3D models.You often get to see really ugly flat pictures instead of beautiful 3D models, and they will ♥♥♥♥ your eyes until you hate the game.3.4 - Textures and Effects4/10Some textures look pretty nice and the effect quality is very high.You're often stunned by the beauty of the environment ...But the rest of the textures real

content:
ry 2, 2014
												What an incredible disappointment.  I loved the X Series, and this one promised to get away from the menu micromanagement that dominated the previous games and be more immersive, which was about my only complaint.  So I am excited to start playing this, and I was amazed at how true it was.  I start out roaming an asteroid field looking for this concept ship that was space's equivalent to Gran Turismo's X-Racer, a ship so ridiculously outperforming and expensive that only the one was ever made and no fleet could afford it.But then the first disappointment.  The devs, for reasons I will never understand, decided to call the ship the Albion Skunk...  They wrote in storyline that you catch during load screens that the name was the Albion Pride but someone hacked the ship's registry and changed it's name, which is pretty weak to me.  And of course, your character sticks with the name because nothing boosts a guy's pride in his super rare, super powerful ship like naming it after an animal synonymous with garbage heaps.  And then while he's trying to get the ship working, he is boarded and his new copilot is introduced.Bad storyline out of the way, I'm ready to rock and roll, and thank god this new lady is some genius engineer because after a few console commands and slaps to the console, we've got engines, boosters, weapons, and other basic functionality.  After a quick "getting your feet wet" dogfight, we land at a station and I once again get to awe at the scope they tried to achieve. Flying around the outer portion of this station are hundreds upon hundreds of ships in line to dock at the numerous facilities the station has to offer. Thankfully, everyone realizes that I am the player, and damnit my time is important, because my slipping through to the front of the line does not get anyone all frisky with the trigger.  Even the cops are all, "Carry on, dude!" as they fly by.I dock and am rewarded with the ability to get out of my ship and wander the space station, various little junk sellable pickups everywhere to make things interesting, and dozens of occupants buying and selling, offering to become pilots or other crew for your ship, or ships you will eventually get.  I do my business and take off, continuing on the storyline mission.  More shooting, and I get to dock at an old frieghter.  Again I get to get out of my ship and explore, and I'm wandering the cargo area of this frieghter.  I can see out the airlock forcefield in the back to space and watch the ship as it moves.  At this point I am floored by how great this game is.Fast forward through a few missions, I am already growing bored.  Docking with a ship gives you one "wander area" with one of something like 4 backdrops.  Even the little loot boxes are all in the same spots. And contain usually the same things.  Junk that'll sell for a couple credits, nothing that will get you anywhere financially, though, if you can even find the guy to sell it.  Space stations are not much better.  It looks like they took the same few space station building modules in a level editor and plugged them together in 3 or 4 different configurations, and after about an hour of work, they called it good.Another gameplay aspect is scanning the space station exterior, ostensibly to find out how the whole thing functions.  And when you get the whole thing scanned, you get a pretty decent stationwide discount and bonus to what you sell.  But this becomes extremely tedious as you are looking for the last module that you can see with your scanners that you haven't scanned, but the little question mark you need to get close to won't appear until you look at it from a very specific angle. Ahh frustration, hell with it, moving on.  You can also get these little hacker drones that you remotely pilot to various points around a station or ship within a certain time to hack them and supposedly take control of the ship, force it to dump its cargo, force better deals at the stations, etc.  It doesn't do any of that.  It is a neat stealth gameplay that forces you to hide from patrolling cops but there is no benefit.  You finish the hack and the game tells you you've completed it.  That is it.  No reward whatsoever.  It was like they planned to have it but never got around to finishing it.Short version:The game started out pretty good but quickly devolved into a game that looked like it was rushed out the door months before it should have been.  I did not cover all of the different things you can do in the game, but the review was long enough as it is.  I recommend staying away from this game, though.  The amount of time I spent in it before getting bored, several hours actually, is way above par.  Most people I talk to gave it about 15 minutes and called it quits.

												A terribly dissapointing release that seems to freeze or crash in a different way each time it's played.  In scale it might be compared to Skyrim, with its impressively large playable area, but X Rebirth lacks any significant diversity within that space.  A small handful of NPC models are cut and pasted throughout identical locations.  Even when unique characters are encountered, their dialog is confused and poorly voice-acted.  And without the option of skipping dialog, in any situation, the repeatitiveness of the characters and situations is compounded.While there is an enjoyable aspect to navigating the bustling space around lovely stations, in beautifully rendered external environments, these potential strengths are mitigated by a horribly muddled UI which includes the claustrophobic and largely non-interactive cockpit of your ship, only a very small portion of which offers any useful information for navigation or combat.As a whole, X Rebirth is a largely broken, badly designed, low-concept product that could use, at minimum, another year in development and a full UI overhaul.  Fans of the series might find the experience worthwhile, but the rest of the gaming community will likely find time and money better spent in Eve.

er 8, 2013
												Even without all the bugs and performance problems, what we have is a very bad game that is poorly designed. It will take you hours upon hours of maneuvering through convoluted gameplay mechanics and glitches just to find out how shallow the game really is. It has taken them "7" years to shovel this garbage out the door. A space sim(?) in which joystick/HOTAS support are held together with scotch tape, no physics (like all X games, it feels like moving around in spectator mode from Counter-Strike 1.5), no freelook (much less TrackIR), no radar, no target filtering, etc. In short - it is a big mess.Some might say it was a failed console game, and by Egosofts own admission they had it working on the Xbox 360 and would love nothing more than to have had X Rebirth as a console game. Instead, they vomited this out on to the PC. I suspect even Microsoft didn't want anything to do with it's poor quality and turned them down.I wouldn't bother waiting for it to get fixed, either. X Rebirth feels like a "last hurrah" to cash out of the business before Star Citizen and Elite Dangerous carry the space sim genre for the next decade. And we will all be better off for it.TRADE: Broken and cumbersome. Lacks information that should be easily accessible. Fly around convoluted space stations and pick up trade offers that only last an hour. Waterboard yourself as you wait 30 minutes for your transport ship to fly to the station and break while trying to complete an order.FIGHT: Incredibly shallow. Fixed view to make you nauseous and you're unable to look around. Cockpit takes up 40% of the screen. No radar or target filtering of any kind. Not even going to go into the AI.BUILD: Broken with an incredible lack of information letting you know wtf is going on or what you're doing wrong/how to do it in the first place. What can you build? AN EMPIRE!? Yeah, sure....some more stations to do more broken trading.THINK: You got that right. You'll spend a lot of time trying to figure out how to do basic things only to find out that they are convoluted or don't exist in the first place. Scratch your head in wonder while asking yourself how this garbage could make it out to retail. Be in awe with the slapped together design decisions. Dabble into the world of conspiracy theories at X Rebirths suspicious release timing just ahead of Star Citizen and Elite Dangerous.

er 30, 2013
												X rebirth is what you get when you take past X games, arguably take the best parts of those games and add a full body avatar to them. The game starts off good but you will find that there are a ton of bugs present in the initial launch game. The game is a pretty good space sim, and extremely detailed. Lots of ships are flying about, space cities and stations that span several kilometers and have intricate workings. Lots to see and lots to do. the same can be said for fights with capital ships, no longer are these behemoths large bludgions that will kill your ship when they as much as take a right turn if you happen to be in their way. And instead of just attacking them to dwindle down their HP, they now have actual hard-points on board that can be destroyed, often after you get past the shield generator that protects them. Destroy the engines, jump drive and docking bay ports can render a ship incapable of defending itsself. But get too close or in line of sight with its AA batteries and there will be hell to pay. Large scale battles between multiple capital ships can be a sight to behold. Small ships on the other hand will swoop around larger objects and seek you out, through they can be easy to kill with the right weaponry.It is certain to say that the combat mechanics of X-rebirth are certainly an improvement.Unfortunately this can not be said about some of its other main mechanics, and this is mostly due to bugs... Lots and lots of bugs...------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Minor bugs that take you out of the game: Like crouching characters and falling through the floor when spawning.- Annoying bugs & behaviour such as: Icons and triggers not loading for at least half a minute after undocking, or the fact that you often need perfect line of sight to see missions. Or being unable to buy items at discount because you can't afford the the item at full price.- Major game breaking bugs such as: Ships that were impounded not being returned to you after a mission is complete, deleting them from the game. Trade ships not functioning like they should, getting stuck.------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Another problem is both the games strength and weakness, SATA, (the time skipping feature used to speed up the game) has been removed. Instead, you will now find highways, high speed routes that cross entire sectors. These highways function great for getting around, (as long as there is traffic on them, otherwise you're still very slow). When off the highways you now have a boost feature (partially to replace SATA) this boost allows you to rapidly accelerate, but in exchange it drains your shields. Its a great feature, but shouldn't be used too much in combat.Initially and AFAIK there is no fast travel to speak of. I suspect you'll be able to hitch a ride later on a capital ship with a jump drive, but I can't say for sure if this is player controled, or just a part of specific missions. Unfortunatly, capital ships seem to lack the boost feature. Meaning that you will often have to wait several minutes for your trade ship to complete its docking procedure after it jumps into the area, something SATA in previous games so nicely circumvented.This is compounded by the sheer size of the game world. Finding a character that sells you something can be a chore or even worse, and this is all because even though the game world is suppose to be defined, the merchants and NPC's, besides the terminals you buy and sell bulk goods from are all randomly generated. So if a character gives you a recommendation for a certain mechanic (npc) with very good stats, that npc won't be there the next time you dock.Characters, like any other installment of the X series, look like they are either 70 years old, or had a serious cosmetic accident. And the voice acting, while not terrible, has some of the worst writing I've ever heard. Don't even get me started on the small talk feature.-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------In conclusion, I guess the campaign is decent, if somewhat stale. Most of the tasks you are asked to do are default sandbox cookie cutter missions such as, Find NPC, Buy/Sell, Deliver, Kill, Scan, Mine, etc. Unfortunately, the few that I found that are unique and contain story telling tend to be quite buggy. The first 5 hours are spend teaching you the ropes on how to play the game. This makes the campaign just a tutorial for the sandbox mode. My advice to people who are considering this game, WAIT.The game is fun to play, if it works... but right now there are too many things broken.Luckily, if EGOSOFT has one saving grace, its that they are pretty good at patching their games. At this time they have already released 20 patches. Give it half a year to a year, pick it up during a steam sale and have the experience this game was suppose to have at launch...

content:
3, 2014
												This was an impulse purchase for me, I had never heard of the "X" series before I bought this game. While most negative reviews here consist of betrayed "X" series fans venting, this review will focus on the gamebreaking bugs/problems.Where to start...I preordered this game one day before it released, from the little snippets of information I could find it looked like a cross between Descent Freespace, Imperium Galactica II, and Sins of a solar Empire.1st person combat in space with a living economy that can be exploited for your gain? Why not?It'd been a few years since I've found a good space sim and was hoping that this one would fill the gap.Installed it and booted up the game, but I couldn't actually start a game without it locking up at the loading screen. After a quick google search I found a fix, I had to lower the sound quality on my sound card...odd to say the least.The space combat was amazing! Graphics were spectacular! Textures were pretty low res on the stations.Now for the bulk of why I recommend you don't buy this game, or at least wait until they fix it. 6+ months from now?Game breaking bugs! I mean really game breaking, CTD, halting progression, raising your blood pressure bugs.They have this cinematic whenever you enter the cockpit, your chair turns towards you and you sit down and it turns back. That's great and all until it breaks and the chair doesn't turn to you, but not only is that broken, everything useful you pull up from this panel that comes popping up from the side is. Only it doesn't if the chair breaks, so you get stuck looking 90 degrees to the right with no options to get out of that view because the only way to cancel it is to hit the "x" that is on the panel that never came up! *restart game*At one point in the game you have to have a cargo carrier of yours deliver power cells. 100 to be exact, out of a 100,000 capactity carrier. Not only does that seem like an absurd waste of time, it has the potential to block you from ever progressing. Once ordered to trade, you cannot cancel the order. Pathing is broken so your carrier might just keep ramming against the station. Or it could fly a few thousand KM away from the station, only to turn around and fly back. Once it actually docks with the station, it might never complete the trade. It will just float there forever. You have to edit your save file to remove the ship from the trade que. *exit game and edit XML files with notepad++*Corrupted saves! Lost seven hours of gameplay because it crashed after I entered a Space Highway.The highways are a gimmick that should have never been added, you have to play bumper tag with the other ships that enter to get a speed boost. Only problem is that sometimes ships never enter so you are stuck at slow speed for the next five minutes. That and you might get kicked out of the highway for no reason what-so-ever, so have fun flying a few hundred thousand KM back to civilization since you can't enter the highway again. *Load game that may or may not be recent*Economy is not what I would call living. Trading is more likely to break your game and takes such an absurdly long time for your ship to go from point A to point B that you can make more money, faster, flying to stations and trading rockets.The devs boasted that you can blow up/capture a cargo carrier full of *insert item here* and watch the prices spike since the supply is now lower than the demand. Either A. They lied. Or B. The game is so broken that it never registered that I vaporized the cargo after I destroyed the ship that carried it.You can just capture a battleship and pawn it off for around 120m credits, that really made trading null so I don't know why they bothered. *Just blow it all up!*Sometimes the game will enable a "noclip" function, you can fly and shoot straight through everything! While amusing for a bit, it becomes less so when you are trying to escort a ship and the mission fails because your projectiles go through the enemy fighters, thus allowing them to blow up the escorted ship at their leisure. Only way to cancel the bug is to reload, which fails the mission anyways, so GG. *try not to cry*Framrate likes to take a dive in this game, especially at highways. Apparently it was a big problem for most people, some people would get 20 frames regardless. I was lucky to be running at 60+, until they put out a patch and it crawled to 25. I'm not using a potato to play this game either. They seriously broke it.There are more, but seriously, the list goes on and on and on. I played 50 hours of this mess.Along with the scores of little bugs that just either break immersion or break whatever else I can't recommend buying this.After really, really wanting to like this game, I found it to be an exercise in frustration. Joke is on me for getting the CE for a game I didn't know jack about.

ry 2, 2014
												What an incredible disappointment.  I loved the X Series, and this one promised to get away from the menu micromanagement that dominated the previous games and be more immersive, which was about my only complaint.  So I am excited to start playing this, and I was amazed at how true it was.  I start out roaming an asteroid field looking for this concept ship that was space's equivalent to Gran Turismo's X-Racer, a ship so ridiculously outperforming and expensive that only the one was ever made and no fleet could afford it.But then the first disappointment.  The devs, for reasons I will never understand, decided to call the ship the Albion Skunk...  They wrote in storyline that you catch during load screens that the name was the Albion Pride but someone hacked the ship's registry and changed it's name, which is pretty weak to me.  And of course, your character sticks with the name because nothing boosts a guy's pride in his super rare, super powerful ship like naming it after an animal synonymous with garbage heaps.  And then while he's trying to get the ship working, he is boarded and his new copilot is introduced.Bad storyline out of the way, I'm ready to rock and roll, and thank god this new lady is some genius engineer because after a few console commands and slaps to the console, we've got engines, boosters, weapons, and other basic functionality.  After a quick "getting your feet wet" dogfight, we land at a station and I once again get to awe at the scope they tried to achieve. Flying around the outer portion of this station are hundreds upon hundreds of ships in line to dock at the numerous facilities the station has to offer. Thankfully, everyone realizes that I am the player, and damnit my time is important, because my slipping through to the front of the line does not get anyone all frisky with the trigger.  Even the cops are all, "Carry on, dude!" as they fly by.I dock and am rewarded with the ability to get out of my ship and wander the space station, various little junk sellable pickups everywhere to make things interesting, and dozens of occupants buying and selling, offering to become pilots or other crew for your ship, or ships you will eventually get.  I do my business and take off, continuing on the storyline mission.  More shooting, and I get to dock at an old frieghter.  Again I get to get out of my ship and explore, and I'm wandering the cargo area of this frieghter.  I can see out the airlock forcefield in the back to space and watch the ship as it moves.  At this point I am floored by how great this game is.Fast forward through a few missions, I am already growing bored.  Docking with a ship gives you one "wander area" with one of something like 4 backdrops.  Even the little loot boxes are all in the same spots. And contain usually the same things.  Junk that'll sell for a couple credits, nothing that will get you anywhere financially, though, if you can even find the guy to sell it.  Space stations are not much better.  It looks like they took the same few space station building modules in a level editor and plugged them together in 3 or 4 different configurations, and after about an hour of work, they called it good.Another gameplay aspect is scanning the space station exterior, ostensibly to find out how the whole thing functions.  And when you get the whole thing scanned, you get a pretty decent stationwide discount and bonus to what you sell.  But this becomes extremely tedious as you are looking for the last module that you can see with your scanners that you haven't scanned, but the little question mark you need to get close to won't appear until you look at it from a very specific angle. Ahh frustration, hell with it, moving on.  You can also get these little hacker drones that you remotely pilot to various points around a station or ship within a certain time to hack them and supposedly take control of the ship, force it to dump its cargo, force better deals at the stations, etc.  It doesn't do any of that.  It is a neat stealth gameplay that forces you to hide from patrolling cops but there is no benefit.  You finish the hack and the game tells you you've completed it.  That is it.  No reward whatsoever.  It was like they planned to have it but never got around to finishing it.Short version:The game started out pretty good but quickly devolved into a game that looked like it was rushed out the door months before it should have been.  I did not cover all of the different things you can do in the game, but the review was long enough as it is.  I recommend staying away from this game, though.  The amount of time I spent in it before getting bored, several hours actually, is way above par.  Most people I talk to gave it about 15 minutes and called it quits.

												Too many bugs. The idea of the game seems fun and I'm really trying, but I have to fight the interface (worse than prior X games) every time I want to do a task. Submenus upon submenus upon submenus, under the menu, only to find that's not the right place to send a fleet command for your non-combat ships to stop following, even though you were looking for fleet commands. Missions are fairly broken as well, you will need to do save game editing to fix/get past some of them. In fact, I'm stuck on selling 300 Food to some station in Fervid something as they won't seem to accept any of the 5,000 Food I've picked up in my Construction Vessel nor a Lepton that has precisely 300 Food on it. Neither of those ships will complete the trade with the mission station. I've heard that I have to buy the 300 Food from a specific station, but the mission never mentions it and the mission "briefs" are just that, brief and uninformative.The walking around in stations is a huge waste of time and is often laggier than being out in space. Trying to do trades in the game is a joke, especially if it's a trade for a mission, your ships will often get "stuck" traveling between systems or even wandering aimlessly around a station and never dock, like its supposed to, to start the trade. I've watched one of my ships (Construction Vessel) dock twice at the correct port, only to never unload its cargo and instead immediately undock. This game is an endless series of frustrations with a few glimmers of joy.I almost forgot to mention your singular ship that you fly, which can only have one gun of a certain type (plasma, mining, etc.) "active" at a-a-time, you cannot have, say, four plasma cannons all blasting away. The only way to upgrade your weapon is to upgrade that one weapon to a strong version. Also, any time you open a menu while your ship is flying, your ship will STOP. So don't even think about multi-tasking while flying to some distant object, even for a brief moment. All forward momentum will immediately cease.Oh, and yes you can capture ships, but only to sell them. In theory you can fly the ships, but as part of your boarding process you destroy the jump engines and drives, which makes the ship incapable of moving and there's no way to repair the ship if it doesn't already have Construction URV drones on it. Some ships don't even have drone bays and it's only a random chance (I have yet to see any included Construction URV drones after capturing 9 vessels) that they would pre-exist. You then put an Engineer on the ship which randomly (or you edited your save game) has Construction URV drones who then may, or may not, repair the ship. I have three Balor class ships sitting around with engineers and Construction URV drones, but the engineers refuse to do anything. One says he's repairing, but it's been 15 hours of in-game time of nothing. The other two engineers aren't even pretending to do their repair work on the engines.Did I mention selling the ships you captured? Well, that's only if you didn't tell one of the first ships to dock at the Ship Trader (you can only modify/sell ships to specific traders that know/want that type of ship) and repair itself, only to find out that the ship cannot move to the repair dock because the engines are destroyed and the engineer won't repair it. Now that Ship Trader is "stuck" on that order and will refuse to do any business with you, including selling any of your other ships. The only way to fix this is, again, to edit your save game and remove the repair order or just delete the offending ship. Also, you need Pilots to capture small ships (e.g. Fighters) and Captains to command the larger capital ships, plus an engineer to (maybe) repair the capital ship, but you may only carry a few (seven I think?) crew on your ship. You need a Marine Officer to even do the boarding, so that's one down already, so don't even bother with Pilots and trying to capture smaller ships. Best bet is to capture the ship, destroy anything Yisha asks you to in order to help the boarding process, and then immediately sell the ship. Don't try to fix anything. If you want a ship, go buy one from a Ship Trader.Seven years in the making? I seriously doubt that, or they spent all their time using developer hacks to do the fun events during QA and never played it like we mere customers would have to.

Instead I shall list suggestions which would make this game's experience fantastic because the original concept is indeed fantastic, but unfortunately not exploited. All I mention here is based on enough hours of playing and completing the whole campaign (thanks to the 1.24 patch).Remember that Egosoft have already invested a lot of time, money and resources for the existing content, so do not expect much improvement on this project. They might decide to release DLCs but these are not solutions to existing problems, they are extensions of existing problems.Here it goes:__________________________________________Hardware-Make the game running smooth on the average modern PCControls-Enable look around using numpad as in X3-Split roll function in two button: roll right, roll left and assignable on gamepad as in X3X Universe-Add Boron and Paranid factions (it's unfair if they come in payable DLC)-Add Pirate stations. If not directly visible give hints, indications that they might be somewhere near some zones and we'd explore for them-Make trade/missions possible with PiratesGraphics-Make MPC characters look and act more realistic-Stations/ships/objects should not be visible while outside nebula cloud-Nebula cloud should be visible from any distance while in the sector, not just from its zone.-Prevent ships going through one another or through stations as if hollowOptional but doable cool and practical graphical suggestions-Make it possible to dock in stations manually with animation of opening hangar and docking procedure (if enabled by player   in settings)-Make it possible to travel in a station from one dock/area to another using a local train or something cool -Make planetary descent possible (limited areas only if too complicated) for trade and exploration, alone or with party (yes it's possible, Evochron series have this fantastic feature with realistic atmospheric characteristics)UI and around instead of the control switch in the corridor-Enable interaction functions with other tools/computers in cockpit for small routine maintenance/monitoring (engineer cannot do everything)-Enable more speech with co-pilot and crew to kill the silence and stillnessNavigation & map-Enable jump drive for Skunk: gate to gate and point to point (unfocused optional but cool)-Enable zoom in/out in map, not just press sector/zone...-Add written details on map for stations, ships and objects, not just clickable list o right side-Enable filter map content for display-Let us select our own speed in It should also be configurable in settings-Don't make enemy fighters stick so close to station like flies on a light bulb__________________________________________Some details might have slipped my mind, however, feel free to add or modify this list. I believe we should put as much pressure as possible on Egosoft on this cause it's really a waste. 												This Game engine is flawed with performance issues for High-end gaming PC's but according to other reports seems to work best with low end CPU's and Video card combo.'s. End results For Higher end gaming PC's: (AMD 6-core @ 4GHz; 8GB-RAM + ATI HD R2-290)> The game can become very laggy due to very, and I do mean very low FPS (5-10 FPS) depending on which area you are in.> Player experience is worse when in larger, big Space Ports with very busy traffic from many ships coming and going. > Player experience is best when in deep space staring into nothingness.> A flurry of patches/fixes are coming in from Egosoft but so far, very few of them have nothing to due with performance gains.> Player experience for Patches/fixes that do address performance gains, range from negligible at worst, to mediocre at best. Still, for many players the game remains unplayable.Conclusion:> This game is for you if you do not mind viewing this more as a "turn based strategy game.">  If not; wait for the patches to fix the game "The Way It's Meant To Be Played". But lets face it; if it were that simple to fix, it would already have been fixed long ago and real performance gains may only be realized incrementally over a very, very long time. This, maybe even mores so if they have to port this over from Directx-9.0c to Directx 11.0 to fully fix the problem.I believe the reason they chose Directx 9.0c is because they thought they could use their experience with it as leverage for a  reduced development time but when the code never gets "Locked" due to continuing feature adaptations then this just stretched the development even more so. (7-years and counting).And of course Directx 9.0c is probably much cheaper to licence per game sold than Directx-11.

content:
er 2, 2013
												Now I realize my review will be just another grain of sand on the beach of Normandy that was the disaster called X Rebirth and that my voice will most likely be drowned out by the shouts and cries of those others who purchased the title alongside me. Close to countless reviews found on just about any gaming website can elucidate the extent of the problems this game presented. I just wanted to highlight some that mattered most to me. Given that it's near impossible to get a game released these days without a slew of bugs and glitches, I don't want to spend too much time focusing on those errors. That said, it is worth asking how on earth a company as established as Egosoft could have possibly thought XR was worthy of release. A few glitches here, maybe a bug or two in that feature there, sure but what they gave us was just an utter shock. And you have to imagine that at some point, they sat down during some meeting just before launch and said "well this is ready to hit the mainstream. We have a good product, a functioning product or at the very least a passable product but as we all know now, not one of those held true. NOT a one. To be frank, as consumers we have a right to expect a game to not have at least half the bugs XR had, especially in a AAA title. I'm not implying that every game released be absolutely bug free, but I equate this to gas prices. At a certain point in time, our country raises gas prices from oh, let’s say $2.00 a gallon to $4.50. Of course we're outraged but this persists for such a long time that when they finally reduce the price to $3.95, we jump for joy and hug our pets in excitement. Again, I don't expect the gas to be free, but I expect it to be reasonable. The games that have been released over the last few years are akin to charging a good $6.00/g for gas and nowhere has this been more true for me than with XR. I was so utterly frustrated doing the infamous 100 energy cell mission within the first hour of the game that my gf had to pull me away and take me to dinner to calm me down a bit but I let the game continue in hopes that my ship would find it’s way. Two and a half hours later and my freighter is still taking a sightseeing tour of whatever galaxy we're in (something I doubt I'll ever learn given the incomprehensible map system). Unfortunately, when I submitted for a refund 4-5 times, Steam laid this  as evidence against me stating I had played 20 some odd hours and therefore must have in some way approved of the product. Like most people I've spoken to or read about, the vast majority of that time was spent alt tabbed checking forums, practicing calming breaths, thinking about taking up religion again or going out to more dinners aimed at diffusing my ticking time bomb of frustration. Many others have stated this very thing in their own way and yet it shows us logging on more hours than we ever actually played. SO that all said, let’s say the Egosoft fairy waived her magic wand, which I'm sure is rife with glitches and probably using the wrong batteries and fixed every bug and glitch in the game. Know what we're left with? An glitch free POS. Look, I'm not trying to be some kind of hater. I, like everyone else tried time and again to justify the money I threw away in this game. And like some others also stated, there is the skeleton of a game buried in there somewhere, but I really did try. I have everything to gain in liking this game given the brick wall I've ran into with steam customer service. All the bugs aside, the design decisions they made in this day and age are just beyond understanding. I understand these guys are based in Germany but could they really not afford getting just one guy, ONE GUY who speaks native English on their staff to share some phrases with them that would pass off better than "Go Boil your Head" or, "Nice talking to you...NOT". Forget how utterly annoying it is that nearly every NPC is angry at you for no reason....well wait, they all appear to be over 70 years old, so maybe they're just old grouches.....that are supposedly piloting space and building empires......sigh.., forget the annoyance, if you can anyhow, but the dialogue left me embarrassed for them in some odd way.  How full of yourself and out of touch must you be? And How many times did Bernd say the word "Immersion"? Yisha, the co-pilot is by far and away on my top three list of hair pullers. Forget her really creepy incomprehensible animation, not sure if she's pooping in her ventilated space suit, is she's part arachnid, fighting the urge to eat me, or doing calisthenics. What I don't understand is why they put her there. I know others have voiced this in their own way, but here's the bottom line. She doesn't do anything. At all. She doesn't pilot, trade, she is nothing more than a permanent plot prop piece. I've tried finding the woman who did the voice acting for her without success. Perhaps that's for the best. She doesn't need career changing advice from some yankee. But oh my sweet jesus is it awful. It again, ruins the whole immersion. Poorly written dialogue, made worse by the worst voice acting. Missions requiring me to go here to pick this up, then there to drop it off, then here to pick up something else, then there to deliver it. I'm a fed ex truck in space stuck on rookie training duty. What i did find funny was how very early in the game, the crew to which Yisha belonged to paid me good money (I'm assuming its good since I haven't really had a chance to see an economy function) to keep her with me. It totally sounds like a made up excuse to get rid of her now that she's no longer on their ship. Out of the  literally 12 times I had to restart the game, that was the only thing that made me smile until I realized it was me they pawned her off on. If I could have ejected her from my latrine shoot, I would have right onto their windshield.  I mean the list goes on and on and on. The one thing everyone was really excited about, or at least most people, myself included, was walking around space stations. God what an exercise in frustration that was. Cookie cutter, with every NPC doing the same task  in the same corner. Every box and locker making the same sound and getting you stuck in the process 25% of the time. It was all just one big horrible horrible horrible experience. And they charged us $50 for it. They made a lot of money while many of us gave a significant chunk of our meagerly paychecks for something we were hoping would take our minds off our meagerly paychecks. Instead, I’m forced to face the harsh realities of just how much spending $50 on the wrong present for myself can impact my life in a negative way. I’ve since moved on but then I saw that Steam is finally allowing us to write reviews so here is me waving my hands telling anyone thinking of XR to change course, go somewhere else. Dive into an empty swimming pool and incur more enjoyment. One a last note, I emailed egosoft early on and the Bernd man himself replied. I wont bother with the details cuz he didn’t give me any. It was short, condescending, blowing off my thoughts and recommendations and still full of himself with regards to that incredibly inappropriate “We’re a Success!” message he tied onto his failing apology. In short all that said was, we failed, you bought it, and we MADE MONEY OFF YOU!!! Yay!Sigh. Hey Egosoft, if any of you ever read this, go and apologize. Not to us cuz that would take the remainder of your lives to do. Rather, apologize to every other gaming company for the bad faith you instilled in all the gamers out there that will inevitably think twice about purchasing something at launch. You screwed up the curve in the worst possible way. So to all of you that made these decisions to the ones that knew better but lacked the courage to tell those in power  what time of day it was and that they’re releasing a big failure, I say SHAME on you.

												This game comes from a franchize that chose to break down the barriers between space sims and RPG's with ground breaking dreams of everything from a stock market to station owning/building to fleet designing and controlles and the ability to fly very nearly ALL ship types in the game (or capture/steel the ones you could not buy).  Yes there were issues and hurdles that had to be over come here and there in previos versions and some that never got resolved; I had hoped that this would be the truth here too as a new direction in this groud breaking thought line.  I have been playing the last 4 itterations of the Xuniverse franchise (I got hooked with the original X2 big time).  I was hoping that maybe all the hype was just due to this being a complete revamp of the entire design, alas this is not completely right, yes it is a revamp but with the redesign I find it more fun to play any space game but this one including DarkStar One, which advertised the same but was a bit of a fun yet still a flop of a game.  I would argue that nearly 90% of the intelligence and aspects of what made the previous game difficult to develop and create were removed or cheated out (Ships would commonly fly THROUGH stations so they do not have to die by the station simply becasue they can not fly around it).  If you wish a list of items that no longer exist then please ping me any time I will give you far greater detail as the game is no longer "A Living Economy" but now a totally fake and DEAD one, and I primise not to just wine because they changed the paint job, this game really does make me very sad that I spent the money to buy it.  I would have been better off spending that money on ANY other game including variants I do not like playing on PC, I hate to support horribly done games and I have to say I really am dissapointed in the developer I tryly enjoy games from (EGSOFT) thinking this was a releasable game (not to mention the number of serious buggs in it), after within only a few minutes of my first maiden flight I got runover by a freighter and pushed "through" the walls of a station and locked inside it making it impossible to escape and having to completely restart the game.  I highly reccoment as a gamer that you stay away from this title, get all of the X3 previous titles if you want to really enjoy a game for a long time and have endless relayability (I normally do not replay game but I have done so MANY times with X3 itterations previous to Rebirth).  I am truly sorry EGSOFT, you really let everyone down on this title, pleaes go back and look at why the previous game was so enjoyed and rethink the architecture including the rendering engine.  I KNOW you can do FAR better then this even in Beta class games.

er 27, 2013
												This game just wasn't ready to be published.  After 21 patches and a month and a half after release, the game is still riddled with bugs.  I'm going to wait about 5 more months to try again as the developers are going to need that time to fix the uncountable issues with the game.  I still can't make it through the campaign without the game asking me to transport someone to some non-existent space station.  The only way people seem to make it through is by modifying the massive save files.  This game is worse than a lot of greenlight games are.  As a programmer I understand building a dynamic universe like this is extremely complex.  There are a lot of complaints about unfinished games being released to early from Battlefield 4 to Diablo 3.  Those games had some understandable problems on release.  This game however, is not even close to playable and can't even be compared to the problems other games have had on release.  I don't blame the developers, I blame the publishers for releasing a game that quite simply is not ready to be played.  I really wanted to like this game and tried really hard to looks past the glaring problems.  I really hope they succeed in fixing the issues and get the game to a playable state.

I’ve since moved on but then I saw that Steam is finally allowing us to write reviews so here is me waving my hands telling anyone thinking of XR to change course, go somewhere else. Dive into an empty swimming pool and incur more enjoyment. One a last note, I emailed egosoft early on and the Bernd man himself replied. I wont bother with the details cuz he didn’t give me any. It was short, condescending, blowing off my thoughts and recommendations and still full of himself with regards to that incredibly inappropriate “We’re a Success!” message he tied onto his failing apology. In short all that said was, we failed, you bought it, and we MADE MONEY OFF YOU!!! Yay!Sigh. Hey Egosoft, if any of you ever read this, go and apologize. Not to us cuz that would take the remainder of your lives to do. Rather, apologize to every other gaming company for the bad faith you instilled in all the gamers out there that will inevitably think twice about purchasing something at launch. You screwed up the curve in the worst possible way. So to all of you that made these decisions to the ones that knew better but lacked the courage to tell those in power  what time of day it was and that they’re releasing a big failure, I say SHAME on you.

												This game comes from a franchize that chose to break down the barriers between space sims and RPG's with ground breaking dreams of everything from a stock market to station owning/building to fleet designing and controlles and the ability to fly very nearly ALL ship types in the game (or capture/steel the ones you could not buy).  Yes there were issues and hurdles that had to be over come here and there in previos versions and some that never got resolved; I had hoped that this would be the truth here too as a new direction in this groud breaking thought line.  I have been playing the last 4 itterations of the Xuniverse franchise (I got hooked with the original X2 big time).  I was hoping that maybe all the hype was just due to this being a complete revamp of the entire design, alas this is not completely right, yes it is a revamp but with the redesign I find it more fun to play any space game but this one including DarkStar One, which advertised the same but was a bit of a fun yet still a flop of a game.  I would argue that nearly 90% of the intelligence and aspects of what made the previous game difficult to develop and create were removed or cheated out (Ships would commonly fly THROUGH stations so they do not have to die by the station simply becasue they can not fly around it).  If you wish a list of items that no longer exist then please ping me any time I will give you far greater detail as the game is no longer "A Living Economy" but now a totally fake and DEAD one, and I primise not to just wine because they changed the paint job, this game really does make me very sad that I spent the money to buy it.  I would have been better off spending that money on ANY other game including variants I do not like playing on PC, I hate to support horribly done games and I have to say I really am dissapointed in the developer I tryly enjoy games from (EGSOFT) thinking this was a releasable game (not to mention the number of serious buggs in it), after within only a few minutes of my first maiden flight I got runover by a freighter and pushed "through" the walls of a station and locked inside it making it impossible to escape and having to completely restart the game.  I highly reccoment as a gamer that you stay away from this title, get all of the X3 previous titles if you want to really enjoy a game for a long time and have endless relayability (I normally do not replay game but I have done so MANY times with X3 itterations previous to Rebirth).  I am truly sorry EGSOFT, you really let everyone down on this title, pleaes go back and look at why the previous game was so enjoyed and rethink the architecture including the rendering engine.  I KNOW you can do FAR better then this even in Beta class games.
